dataset.title: Effects of browsing and season on defence and growth of selected woody species at the Nkuhlu exclosures

abstract.para: The study species represented two broad types of shoot morphology, which affected the way in which some data were collected. A. grandicornuta, A. exuvialis and D. cinerea can increase leaf area without increasing internode length. They therefore produce most of their new leaves in discrete clusters (whorls or tufts) of leaves at the nodes of old shoots or branches. The nodes are usually raised into short-shoots or spurs. Conversely, C. apiculatum, G. flavescens and E. divinorum cannot increase leaf area without extending the internodes of new long-shoots. All their new leaves are therefore arranged in either alternate or opposite positions on new shoots. The wet seasons occurring between August 2005 and July 2008 were divided into early (late November/early December), middle (late January/early February) and late (late March/early April) phases. Mature leaves above 1.5 m on randomly selected trees taller than 2 m were sampled in each phase of each wet season. The amount of canopy removed by browsing was estimated for each sampled tree. Concentrations of N, P, condensed tannins, total polyphenols, neutral detergent fibre, acid detergent fibre and acid detergent lignin ([N], [P], [CT], [TP], [NDF], [ADF] and [ADL]) were analysed. Shoot length, leaf length and photosynthesis parameters were measured each time leaves were sampled for chemical analysis in either one or two of the wet seasons. We also explored low-molecular-weight phenolics (LMWPs) in the study species in February/March 2007. Lastly, we fitted dendrometers to the study species in 2006 to measure relative growth rates of stems, which continued until 2012.

keywordSet.keyword: browse, catena, dendrometer, elephants, forage quality, herbivores, nutrients, phenolics, photosynthesis, plant community, plant population, shoot growth, shrubs, spines, stem growth, tannins, trees
SANParks, South Africa, Kruger National Park, South Africa

intellectualRights.para: Sharing of the data is restricted to project members until the end of 2014.

section.title: Chemical composition
section.para: Data on chemical composition were collected in two main phases from the areas protected by fire-breaks. The preliminary phase was aimed at determining general trends across two wet seasons (2005/2006 and 2006/2007) that could be used to focus sampling in the final phase (2007/2008 wet season). The preliminary phase was characterized by collecting samples of each species at 6 random sites per soil type per treatment (18 sites per soil type) during the early, middle and late stages of each wet season (i.e., late November/early December, late January/early February and late March/early April). Samples of two species were also collected in one dry season (June 2007) during the preliminary phase (the other species could not be sampled because they had no leaves). The number of species sampled for chemical analysis in the final phase was reduced from six to four (A. grandicornuta, D. cinerea, G. flavescens and C. apiculatum) for logistical and technical reasons (i.e., sampling fewer species would allow the opportunity to increase sample size per species). The four species were selected because (1) it was not always possible to know the ages of mature leaves on E. divinorum (<1 year or 1-2 years) and therefore it was difficult to control the age of samples collected, and (2) the small, sparse leaves on A. exuvialis were difficult to harvest. The final phase had two objectives. The first objective was to determine herbivore effects on these four species in the middle of the 2007/2008 wet season. It was characterized by collecting samples at 18 random sites per soil type per treatment (54 sites per soil type) in late January 2008. An exception was G. flavescens, which could not be found at 13 of the 54 sites visited on the crest and midslope. The second aim of the final phase was to continue our study of seasonal variations by sampling at different times of the 2007/2008 wet season, but sampling was restricted to 6 plants per species in the total exclusion plot. A 30x30 m grid based on the “UTM WGS 84” coordinate system was imposed on a LIDAR image of the study area and the X and Y coordinates at the centre of each grid cell were determined. The sample sites were selected by sorting the central coordinates of each cell in random order and using a Garmin® GPS 72 to navigate to each of the selected sites. Grid cells that occurred on an anomalous basaltic outcrop covering about 15% of the partial exclusion plot were not included in sampling. One tree of each study species was sampled in each grid cell on condition that it was (1) closest to the grid cell centre, (2) taller than 2 m, and (3) neither obviously stressed by disease or neighbours nor obviously growing in a nutrient enriched patch such as a termite mound or localized depression. The minimum height of selected G. flavescens plants was 1.5 m because it seldom grows taller than 2 m. If any of the conditions failed to be met for the closest tree, then the next closest tree that met the conditions was sampled. No tree was sampled if the closest suitable tree was further than 15 m from the grid-cell centre because a neighbouring cell would be entered. Leaf samples were collected by clipping branches 3-8 mm in diameter from the northern, sunlit half of the canopy between 1.5 and 2.2 m above ground, which was within the range of most browsers in the study area. For G. flavescens, branches were collected above 1.0 m. Branches were collected between 1 and 4 hours after sunrise. Mature (fully expanded) leaves that did not show signs of severe insect herbivory were removed until a fresh mass of 30-50 g was obtained for drying in an oven for 24 hours at 60 °C. The only time we deviated from this approach was at the start of the project in November 2005 when sampling was done at an early stage of leaf growth. Dried leaf samples were milled to pass a sieve with 1.0 mm apertures and were analysed for concentrations of condensed tannins (CT) (Porter et al. 1986; Hattas et al. 2005), total polyphenols (TP) (Price & Butler 1977), Kjeldahl-N (AOAC 1984) and P (Murphy & Riley 1962). Sorghum tannin and gallic acid were used as standards for [CT] and [TP]. Concentrations of neutral detergent fibre (NDF), acid detergent fibre (ADF) and acid detergent lignin (ADL) were determined according to Van Soest et al. (1991). All concentrations were expressed as mg g-1 dry mass. All analyses were conducted at the Department of Botany, University of Cape Town. Because the impact of browsing was variable on sampled trees outside the total exclusion plot, estimates of the proportion (%) of productive (potentially leaf- or shoot-bearing) canopy volume below or above 1.5 m deemed to be missing because of (1) leaf removal, (2) biting of current wet season’s shoots, (3) recent browsing of twigs (previous seasons’ shoots), and (4) accumulated browsing of twigs, was recorded for each tree sampled in January 2008. This method was a subjective method, but it was developed and tested by four observers over the course of four sampling occasions between November 2006 and March 2007. Only one of the four observers who calibrated each other during the development stage did the observations in January 2008. Thirty mature leaves were collected from three individuals per species in the total exclusion plot and control plot in early February 2007 and late March 2007 to identify and quantify specific low molecular weight phenolics (LMWPs). The samples were frozen in liquid N and kept frozen until they were freeze-dried. They were later analysed at the Natural Products Laboratories at Joensuu University, Finland, using High Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC) and HPLC coupled to Mass Spectrophotometry (HPLC-MS) (Julkunen Tiitto et al. 1996; Keski-Saari et al. 2005). LMWP concentrations were determined individually, which allowed later combining into functional groups (phenolic glycosides, flavone aglycosides and hydrolysable tannins).

section.title: Shoot length
section.para: Lengths of marked new shoots and new leaves on each species were measured each time leaves were sampled for chemical analysis in the 2006/2007 wet season. Up to 10 new shoots and 10 new leaves on the new shoots were selected on five trees per species in each treatment in the third week of November 2006. The new shoots were selected by randomly locating 10 old shoots (from a previous wet season) per tree. Each selected old shoot was 2-8 mm in basal diameter and 1.5-2.5 m above ground (>1 m for G. flavescens). Old shoots were marked by loosely twisting short pieces of thin “telephone” wire around the shoot base. Colour combinations were used to differentiate individual shoots. The most distal new shoot on each old shoot was marked by painting a small spot of white “correction fluid” (Tippex) at the base. The length of each marked new shoot was measured to the nearest 0.1 cm. Shoots were measured from the base of the shoot to the base of the apical bud. In addition to marking new shoots on A. exuvialis, A. grandicornuta and D. cinerea, which had very few new shoots in November 2006, one leaf cluster was marked on each marked old shoot. The leaf cluster with the longest leaf was marked with a small spot of Tippex painted on the old shoot. The length of the longest leaf on each marked new shoot of all species and the longest leaf in each marked leaf cluster of the “short-shoot” species was measured to the nearest 0.1 mm. Leaves were measured from the base of the petiole to the apex of the midrib (simple leaves) or rachis (compound leaves). None of the A. grandicornuta trees selected for measuring shoot and leaf length had >2 new shoots and the total number of marked new shoots ended up being only 3-5 per treatment. The total number of new shoots marked per treatment for the remaining species was 5-7 on A. exuvialis (1-5 per tree), 1-9 on E. divinorum (1-6 per tree), 40-49 on C. apiculatum (4-10 per tree), 49-50 on G. flavescens (9-10 per tree) and 14-23 on D. cinerea (1-8 per tree). The range in lengths of new shoots was 2.1-6.9 cm in A. exuvialis, 1.0-3.4 cm in E. divinorum, 1.2-3.9 cm in C. apiculatum, 1.2-4.6 cm in G. flavescens and 0.7-6.2 cm in D. cinerea at the time of marking. The low number of new shoots on E. divinorum at the start of the wet season was because of its phenological pattern of producing new shoots later in the season. Each marked shoot that still had an intact apical bud in the first week of December, last week of January and last week of March was re-measured. The longest leaf on each marked shoot was also re-measured. Shoots found to be dead, browsed or missing from the sample population were not replaced. In the first week of November 2007, the lengths of up to 10 randomly selected, unmarked new shoots were measured on each of the trees used for growth measurements in 2006/2007. This time, the objective was to test if there was an effect of herbivore exclusion on shoot length. We did this early in the wet season because as the season progresses many current season’s shoots become damaged and therefore cannot be used to measure effects on growth rate. The early wet season is the best time to find abundant intact new shoots.

section.title: Photosynthesis.
section.para: Maximum (light saturated) photosynthesis rate (Amax) was estimated in the total exclusion plot when leaves were sampled for chemical analysis and shoot lengths were measured in the 2006/2007 wet season. Specific leaf area (SLA, m2 g-1) was estimated each time for calculating Amax per unit mass (Amass). Our focus was on two broad-leaf species (C. apiculatum and G. flavescens) because of technical and logistical constraints (i.e., broad leaves are simpler to measure than fine leaves and both species occurred at each sample site on the crest). Amax was estimated using a LI-6400 photosynthesis system (LI-COR, Nebraska, USA). The leaf chamber was fitted with an internal red-blue light source and photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) was kept at 1200 μmol m-2 s-1. [CO2] in the chamber was maintained at 400 μmol CO2 m-2 s-1. On each sampling day in the early wet season (7 December 2006), mid wet season (6 February 2007) and late wet season (26 March 2007) we estimated the photosynthetic rate of three individuals per species in the total exclusion plot between 06:30 and 08:30 and assumed that the observations approximated Amax. Preliminary observation in April 2006 had indicated that Amax was likely to be achieved between 06:30 and 08:30. The sampled trees were selected from those used for growth measurements. Each time an individual was observed 3-5 fully expanded new leaves between 1 and 2 m were selected for measurement. Each individual was observed once during sampling and therefore the observations were instantaneous “snapshots”. Amax was also measured in the control plot (no exclusion) in February 2007 using the same methods. Amax of C. apiculatum and G. flavescens was estimated again in the total exclusion plot and the control plot in November 2007 (early wet season), February 2008 (mid wet season) and December 2008 (early wet season) using a LI-6400 photosynthesis system. The dry conditions that characterised the 2007/2008 wet season resulted in measurements of Amax in March 2008 being abandoned. The main aim on these occasions was to test the exclosure effect, but we used different methods. In November 2007 we collected diurnal data to make sure we measured Amax at the correct time of day. This required us to observe trees close to each other (<15 m apart) so that we could easily obtain a sequence of observations during the day, which meant that we could not observe the trees used for growth measurements because they were about 100 m apart from each other. The LI-6400 was fitted with a clear leaf chamber for diurnal measurements, which required sunny weather. Only C. apiculatum was observed in November because cloudy conditions limited the available time for measurements on G. flavescens. Whenever the leaf chamber was clamped on a leaf, it was positioned at an angle that would permit maximum sunlight to reach the leaf surface. [CO2] in the chamber was maintained at 400 μmol CO2 m-2 s-1. Each time an individual was observed three fully expanded new leaves between 1 and 2 m were selected for measurement. On two pairs of successive days photosynthetic rates (A) were measured on three individuals 1-2 m tall (19-20 November) and three individuals 2-5 m tall (26-27 November) in close proximity to each other within each plot throughout most of each day starting between 05:30 and 06:00 (30-60 minutes after sunrise). PAR on 26 and 27 November reached saturating levels before 06:30. The shorter trees served as a pilot study before observing the taller trees. In the first week of February 2008 and first week of December 2008 we collected photosynthesis data inside and outside the total exclusion plot by modeling [CO2] response curves. This method gives insights into how internal, biochemical regulators of photosynthesis are responding to external factors by allowing the calculation of carboxylation rates (Vcmax) and electron transport rates (Jmax). The method is also more efficient than estimating Amax on a number of trees during a specific observation period when Amax is assumed to be achieved. Light saturated Amax (at a specific temperature and [CO2]) can be estimated, although values may not be directly comparable to those obtained under ambient conditions when light or temperature are not controlled. The method is not dependent on weather conditions or time of day, which means that more trees can be sampled per day regardless of cloud cover (except in wet weather). In the week of 4-8 February 2008 four individuals of each species were observed in the total exclusion plot and four in the control plot. Three fully expanded new leaves between 1 and 2 m were selected for measurement on each tree. Measurements on each leaf took approximately 15 minutes and four trees could be observed per day between 06:30 and 09:30. The “A-CiCurve” program of the LI-6400 was used to expose each leaf to variable [CO2] following a sequence of 400, 300, 200, 100, 50, 400, 400, 600 and 800 μmol m-2 s-1 (LI-COR 2004). Each leaf was allowed at least 1 minute (but not more than 2) to stabilize after each change in [CO2] before A was logged. [CO2] flow rate was kept at 400 μmol m-2 s-1. PAR was kept at 1500 μmol m-2 s-1 for C. apiculatum and 1100 μmol m-2 s-1 for G. flavescens, while leaf temperature was set at 30 °C, based on light response curves done previously at 25, 30 and 35 °C. Actual leaf temperature averaged 30.8 °C (27.9-34.0 °C). The same procedure was used during the period 4-11 December 2008, except that each leaf was exposed this time to [CO2] following a sequence of 400, 300, 200, 100, 50, 400, 600, 800, 1000 and 1200 μmol m-2 s-1. Two calibrated LI-6400 instruments were used simultaneously each day in the total exclusion plot and control plot. Although the aim was to observe a total of 12 trees per species per plot (8 per day across both plots), technical problems resulted in fewer trees being observed per plot. Actual leaf temperature averaged 29.2 °C (23.7-32.6 °C).

section.title: Dendrometers
section.para: Manual dendrometers (Agricultural Electronics Corp., Arizona, USA) were fitted to 90 individuals of 6 species in August 2006 and February 2007 (5 trees per exclusion plot per species). Most of these were the same individuals on which shoot growth was measured in 2006/2007. A few individuals fitted in February 2007 were not the same because new trees were selected at some sites if the original tree selected was found to be not ideal. Trees were selected according to the same criteria used to select trees for leaf sampling. Dendrometer bands were fitted at a height of 20 cm on the dominant stem (usually the tallest) because a preliminary survey indicated that stems were often fused or unevenly shaped below 20 cm. Circumferences at 20 cm were roughly 10-20 cm for G. flavescens, A. exuvialis and D. cinerea, 15-25 cm for E. divinorum, 25-35 cm for C. apiculatum, and 40-50 cm for A. grandicornuta. Low tension dendrometers were used except on the largest A. grandicornuta stems, which had high tension dendrometers fitted. The dendrometers were observed (nearest 0.1 mm) whenever other fieldwork was being done. Dendrometers were adjusted and circumferences re-measured whenever the reading was 0 or >25.0. Up to July 2008, two G. flavescens shrubs (sites 10011 and 10013) in the control plot were uprooted and the dendrometers damaged, a third G. flavescens shrub (site 10014) was partially uprooted (but the dendrometer was undamaged and the stem remained rooted), one A. grandicornuta tree was felled (site 10020) in the control plot, one A. exuvialis tree in the control plot died (site 10013) and a replacement tree was fitted at the same site in November 2006, and two dendrometers on A. exuvialis trees (sites 10023 and 10024) were damaged in the partial exclusion plot. Apart from fitting one replacement of A. exuvialis (site 10013) in November 2006, no replacement trees were fitted and no damaged dendrometers were repaired until November 2008. The slow growth rate expected of trees in semi-arid climates and the high variation in circumferences at 20 cm among randomly selected trees led us to presume that exclusion effects could not really be tested until a long-term series of data on relative growth rate becomes available. A further 147 new dendrometers were fitted and 3 repaired or replaced in November 2008 with a view to monitoring a total of 237 dendrometers for the next 4-5 years (Tables 1 and 2). Trees were selected according to the same criteria used to select trees for leaf sampling. Two damaged dendrometers on A. exuvialis trees (sites 10023 and 10024) were repaired and a replacement A. grandicornuta tree was fitted at site 10020. The two uprooted G. flavescens shrubs were not replaced. Seven new trees were fitted per species in each of the two exclusion plots, making the total of 12 per species in each of those plots. Extra dendrometers were fitted in the control plot to allow for estimated losses over the next 5 years. Ten new dendrometers were fitted per species in the control, except for G. flavescens for which 15 new dendrometers were fitted because it seemed to be most susceptible to uprooting (at five sites in the control plot only G. flavescens was fitted). At two sites (10082 and 10087) in the partial exclusion plot no G. flavescens was fitted because no suitable plants were found, but at two sites (10081 and 10083) two G. flavescens were fitted to make up the shortfall. In December 2008, it was found that one of the original five A. exuvialis in the total exclusion plot (site 10004) and two in the partial exclusion plot (sites 10021 and 10022) had died. It was also found that of the new trees fitted in November 2008 two A. exuvialis in the control plot (sites 10054 and 10058) and one in the partial exclusion plot (site 10083) had died. Whether they died as a result of the dendrometers being fitted or as a result of low rainfall in 2008 (or a combination thereof) is unclear. The fact that three trees out of nine that had dendrometers on them since late 2006 did not die for two years, and that other A. exuvialis trees without dendrometers were dead in December 2008 indicates that low rainfall was the main cause of death, but the presence of dendrometers cannot be discounted as a contributing factor. Replacement trees were fitted in March 2009.

Table 1. Number of individuals per species that had dendrometers on them in November 2008. Fifteen were fitted per species in August 2006 and February 2007, while 24-27 were fitted per species in November 2008.

Table 2. List of sites, their coordinates and the species fitted with dendrometers at Nkuhlu between September 2006 and November 2008. Sites 10001 to 10030 were fitted in September 2006 and February 2007. Sites 10031 to 10097 were fitted in November 2008.

section.title: Other data collection
section.para: The main focus of all the above research was on individuals 2-5 m tall, but other projects were added to the main project in 2007/2008 to focus on various aspects of individuals shorter than 1.5 m at the exclusion plots (see report submitted to SANParks in September 2007). These projects on short trees were done to study (1) chemical defences, nutrients, growth and photosynthesis of A. grandicornuta, D. cinerea, G. flavescens and C. apiculatum in relation to season and browsing, (2) population structure, and community composition in relation to exclusion and soil type, and (3) physical defences of A. grandicornuta and A. exuvialis in relation to exclusion. The study on the chemistry, growth and photosynthesis of A. grandicornuta, D. cinerea, G. flavescens and C. apiculatum followed basically the same procedures as the “main” study, except for the following differences. Leaves were collected from 10 randomly selected plants (40-50 leaves per plant) per treatment plot per species during the periods 25- 31 Oct 2007, 13-16 Nov 2007, 31 Jan 2008, and 17-19 March 2008. No plants of A. grandicornuta were sampled in November 2007 because suitable individuals were not found at most of the random points visited. The leaves were oven-dried at 60 °C and analysed for concentrations of N, P and condensed tannins. Ten plants per treatment plot were randomly selected in September 2007 and their heights and stem circumferences (at 10cm) were measured. New shoots were marked and their lengths measured on these plants (5 shoots per plant) during the period 23-24 Oct 2007. The lengths of the marked shoots were re-measured during the periods 29-30 Oct 2007, 6 Dec 2007, 1 Feb 2008 and 17-19 Mar 2008. The heights and stem circumferences were re-measured in March 2008. The trees used for shoot growth measurements were used for leaf sampling in March 2008, as well as for photosynthesis measurements in November, February and March. Photosynthesis rate was measured for 3 leaves on each marked C. apiculatum and G. flavescens plant in the total exclusion plot and the control plot between 06:00 and 09:30 on 13-14 November 2007. Responses of photosynthesis to a range of [CO2] were measured for C. apiculatum in the total exclusion plot and the control plot during the period 28-30 November 2007 (PAR=1500; Temp = 30 °C), and again for both C. apiculatum and G. flavescens in the total exclusion plot and the control plot during the periods 6-13 February 2008 and 20-21 March 2008. Measurements were for three plants per treatment per species, except in March when two plants were measured per treatment per species.

For the other studies of plants <1.5 m, transects were surveyed in November and December 2007. Thirty 2x40m transects were randomly placed in each of the three treatments (15 on crest and 15 on footslope) using the same 30x30 m grid mentioned previously. The starting point for each transect was the centre of each grid cell, which was located using a GPS. All transects were placed north of the fire break in the total exclusion plot and south of the fire break in the partial exclusion plot, and well within the borders of each vegetation type. No transects were placed within 30 m of firebreaks or fences. The anomalous area of vegetation in the partial exclusion plot mentioned above was excluded. Between crest and footslope a 30 m zone was observed where no transects were placed. At each starting point, a magnetic compass was used to drag a 20-m chain in a straight line towards magnetic north. At every 1-m mark on the chain we recorded whether or not a line projected up or down intercepted either woody or herbaceous canopy to estimate canopy cover. The species, height (cm), number of stems <1 cm diameter, number of stems >1 cm diameter, and the diameter of the largest stem of every woody plant within 1 m of the chain was recorded. Stem diameters were estimated at 1 cm above ground (i.e., immediately above the basal swelling of the stem). Stems more than 50 cm apart were considered separate individuals. Browsing of individuals shorter than 150 cm was estimated using a method based on the one described above. Browsing estimations included leaf herbivory (% of total leaf area lost), number of unbrowsed/browsed shoots (except where there were too many shoots to count, in which case proportion shoots browsed was estimated) and accumulated browsing (% total biomass above ground lost). Evidence of browsing by black rhino (angular bites) was also recorded. Only browsing by mammals was recorded and shoots were only recorded as browsed when the apex had been removed. For the accumulated browsing no distinction was made between actual browsing and breakage, since elephants can break branches and stems to gain access to certain parts of a plant. There are problems with browsing estimations such as these. First there can be differences depending on who does the estimation, which was avoided by ensuring that the same people did the estimates in all treatments. Secondly a plant may have been browsed in the past but in such a way that it is very difficult to see, and as a result there might be over estimation of unbrowsed individuals. The first individual of Acacia exuvialis or Acacia grandicornuta in each transect was chosen for shoot measurements. Individuals were not chosen if taller than 150 cm or if the accumulated browsing exceeded 50 %, because taller trees would be difficult to measure, and very heavily browsed trees could be too damaged to respond to treatment effects. The selected plants also had to have at least five measurable annual shoots. In cases where no such tree could be found within a transect, the closest suitable tree to the transect starting point (without entering the vicinity of another point) was selected. On the chosen individual, 5-10 annual shoots were selected randomly (the number depending on how many could be found). On these shoots, measurements of shoot length, longest leaf, number of spines and the longest spine in each pair of spines were taken. All spines shorter than 2 mm were excluded. Shoot length was measured from the shoot base to the base of the apical bud, and spine length from spine base to spine tip. The length of each leaf was measured from the base of the petiole to the base of the terminal pinnae.
